A recent study conducted by researchers from climate institutions has revealed that climate patterns from the past provide valuable information about how precipitation will change in the coming decades. However, researchers warn that future climate projections cannot be based solely on historical patterns, since the intensity of current global warming is significantly greater than in previous periods.

The research involves a multidisciplinary analysis combining data from ice cores, lake sediments, and tree rings. These paleoclimatic indicators have allowed scientists to reconstruct climate conditions from thousands of years ago with surprising precision. The implications of this work are profound for planning climate change mitigation and adaptation policies.
